journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications

title-group.article-title: A buckling analysis of perfect and imperfect functionally graded columns

contrib-group.aff: Infra Technology Service, Co. Ltd, Bangkok, Thailand

abstract.p: Due to the asymmetry of the material properties about the middle plane, perfect columns made of functionally graded materials (FGMs) may not remain straight when a compressive axial point load is concentrically applied. This article analytically derives the displacement functions and the buckling load of both perfect and imperfect Euler–Bernoulli functionally graded columns. The method of derivation is based on the translation of the reference plane to the position at which the coupling between the axial and bending deformations is eliminated, i.e. the physical neutral surface position. Then, all the governing equations and their solutions turn out to have the same form as those of homogeneous columns subjected to an eccentric axial load. The effects of geometric imperfection are studied with the main purpose of finding imperfect shapes that make an imperfect column stronger than a perfect one. Further, the governing equations that are used to find those analytical solutions are expanded so that the equations can deal with large deformation and large strain analysis. These new governing equations are solved by finite element (FE) method based on linear exact shape functions. Then, the FE solutions are used to compare and validate the analytical solutions obtained earlier.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Functionally graded materials (FGMs) are composite materials initially developed for the purpose of thermal stress relaxation. Typically, FGMs are composed of two different material constituents whose volume fractions change continuously from one surface to the other. In addition to thermal stress relaxation, FGMs are also used for other purposes such as providing a combination of good elasticity and rigidity in materials used to construct sport equipment.

A number of research papers have presented the buckling analyses of structures made of FGM. Studies that focus on FGM plates under in-plane mechanical loads include those by Feldman and Aboudi [1], Javaheri and Eslami [2], Najafizadeh and Eslami [3], Chen and Liew [4], Ganapathi et al. [5], and Shariat et al. [6]. These papers use the eigenvalue approach to establish the critical buckling load. However, recently, Aydogdu [7] and Prakash et al. [8] pointed out that only clamped plates exhibit the bifurcation type of buckling; therefore, only these plates lend themselves to eigenvalue analysis. Thus, the results presented in earlier studies may not reveal the actual behaviour of the structure. Fewer studies have been published on the buckling of FGM columns subjected to an axial mechanical load. Among these are studies by Elishakoff et al. [9] and Singh and Li [10], which focused on the buckling of axially graded FGM columns. In addition, Huang and Li [11] analysed the stability of FGM circular columns whose material properties vary along the radial direction. It should be noted here that such structures exhibit bifurcation buckling in nature; therefore, the eigenvalue approach is suitable for analysing them. On the other hand, Yang and Chen [12] studied the buckling of FGM beams with edge cracks using the eigenvalue approach. Thus, their results are valid only when the axial load is applied through the physical neutral surface so that the beams can exhibit bifurcation buckling.

This article offers an analysis of the non-linear buckling of perfect and imperfect Euler–Bernoulli FGM columns under a compressive axial point load applied concentrically. The method used derives the governing equations by translating the reference plane to the position at which the coupling between the axial and bending deformations vanishes, i.e. the physical neutral surface position. This approach has already been used to analyse FGM plates by Prakash et al. [8], Morimoto et al. [13], Abrate [14], and Zhang and Zhou [15]. In addition, Li et al. [16] and Kang and Li [17] have drawn on the same idea in studying FGM beams. The main merit of this approach when applied to beams is that the governing equations take on the same form as those of the homogenous beams. However, force and displacement boundary conditions that normally apply at the middle surface must also be transformed in order to be applicable tothe variables of the coordinate system translated to the physical neutral surface. The same idea is alsoapplicable to the finite element (FE) method, e.g. Taeprasartsit [18] explained a procedure to use ANSYS’s BEAM3 element to analyse FGM beams subjected to both mechanical and thermal loads for linear static analysis.

Because the governing equations used to find analytical buckling solutions in this article include non-linear effect only from using von Karman strain, the suitability of those solutions should be checked withsolutions from a more general theory. Thus, a largedeformation thin beam theory for analysing imperfect functionally graded beams is proposed in section 5. Also, the FE equations for solving governing equations of that beam theory are derived using linear exact shape functions. Then, in section 6, a comparison between analytical and FE solutions is made.

sec.title: 2 ANALYTICAL SOLUTION
sec.p: In order to establish the buckling load of the columns, it is necessary to adopt a non-linear beam theory. Here, the non-linearity comes solely from using von Karman strains instead of relying on a linear strain–displacement relation. Then, the governing equations are analogous to those used to find the classical buckling load of homogeneous columns. In the case of perfect homogeneous columns, the buckling load can be obtained from eigenvalue analysis because the columns remain straight under a compressive concentric load. On the other hand, for FGM columns whose support is not of the clamped–clamped type, bifurcation does not take place. It is necessary, therefore, to find the buckling load directly from the load–deflection curve.

The geometry, coordinate system, and sign convention are shown in Fig. 1. Fig. 1
Column geometry, coordinate system, and sign convention

The definitions of lateral displacement w and initial imperfect shape w0 are shown in Fig. 2. Note that subscript 0 indicates imperfection whereas superscript 0 variables on the middle plane. Fig. 2
Imperfect column
The compressive axial point load applied at the centroid of the cross-section of the right end (x = L) is the only external load considered in this article.

When this is done, the x - y plane does not coincide with the middle plane. Also, superscript 0 is replaced by * in order to denote the relation with the translated coordinate system.
After the coordinate axes have been translated, equation (15) becomes (17)

The sign convention of p is the same as that of Fx. That is, the compressive p at the right end has a negative value.

It can be seen that in the first three cases, moment loads appear in the analysis after the axes have been translated. Also, these moments cause the columns to bend under a concentric compressive load. On the other hand, the boundary condition’s (B.C.’s) of the clamped–clamped FGM columns are exactly the same as those of the clamped–clamped homogeneous columns. That is, the clamped–clamped FGM columns exhibit bifurcation buckling in the similar way as do the homogeneous columns; therefore, the clamped–clamped FGM columns are not studied further in this article.

It can be seen that all the above solutions are in the same form as those of the homogeneous columns subjected to an eccentric load. Specifically, dz is just replaced by eccentricity and Dxx by EI, then equations (23) to (28) will change to the classical displacement and buckling load solutions of the homogeneous columns under an eccentric load (c.f., for example, Simitses and Hodges [19]). That is, the FGM columns under a concentric load behave like homogeneous columns under an eccentric load.

sec.title: 3 POSITION OF THE PHYSICAL NEUTRAL SURFACE AND THE EFFECTS OF THE MATERIAL PROPERTY VARIATION
sec.p: The term dz is the distance that the coordinate axes are translated in the z-direction. Its sign conventions are plus for upward and minus for downward.

The material property variation law considered here is the power law as introduced by Wakashima et al. [20]. The law states that (31)
where hdenotes column thickness, Г(z) a typical material property, Гt and Гb the values of the properties at the topmost (z = h/2) and bottommost (z = - h/2) layers of the column, respectively, and k a variable parameter, the magnitude of which determines the curvature. The working range of kcan be taken as 1/3 to 3, as any value outside this range will produce an FGM with too much of one phase.
When the centroid of the cross-section is at half-thickness of the column, then it is required that the value of dzis found that makes (32)
Such dzfor rectangular columns is (33)
From equation (33) and k > 0, it is seen that dzis positive whenever Et > Eb and vice versa. In other words, the physical neutral surface always shifts towards the stronger constituent side.

Also, after translating axes for the distance dz, Axxand Dxxof the rectangular column are found from (34)

sec.title: 4.1 Finding P causing bifurcation
sec.p:
As stated above, for a perfect FGM column under a concentric axial load, bifurcation does not take place. Its load–deflection curve for dz > 0 is plotted in Fig. 8. Obviously, ρthat makes dz (sec ρ - 1) unbounded is ρ = π/2, 3π/2, 5π/2, …. Also, the second term on the right-hand side of equation (35) is considered (36)
Fig. 8
Load–deflection curve for a perfect FGM column

It can be seen that the sequence ρ = π/2, 3π/2, 5π/2, … also causes terms on theright-hand side of equation (36) to become unbounded term by term. This means that if an appropriate value for b1 is chosen, w*(L/2) can be made bounded at ρ = π/2. Similarly, appropriate values for b3, b5, … can render w*(L/2) bounded at ρ = 3π/2, 5π/2, … respectively. A simple method to find the appropriate values of bn is given as follows.

Then, b1 which makes the imperfect column stronger than the perfect one is (44)

sec.title: 5 SOLUTION FROM A LARGE DEFORMATION BEAM THEORY
sec.p: The formulation presented above is given in a traditional way and the governing equation of w* is in fact a linear one. The suitability of analytical solutions obtained so far will be compared with FE solutions of a large deformation beam theory proposed in this section. The formulation in section 2 may be not suitable for large deformation analysis because it uses a set of approximate relations. Now, those relations will be replaced with ones that are more general.

sec.title: 6 COMPARISON BETWEEN THE ANALYTICAL SOLUTIONS AND THE FE SOLUTIONS
sec.p: In this section, the analytical solutions derived in sections 2 and 4 will be compared with solutions of the FE equations derived in section 5. In all numerical examples, columns are assumed to be made of FGM composed of Tungsten (W) and Copper (Cu). W dominates the topmost layer and Cu the bottommost layer, and their Young’s moduli are 411 GPa and 120 GPa, respectively. Further, the cross-section of columns is 1 × 1 m2.

sec.title: 6.1 Example 1: effect of L/h ratio
sec.p:
For material variation parameter k = 1/3, the transverse displacement of the point at the mid-length of pinned–pinned imperfect column is presented for L/h = 20, 30, 40, and 100. The imperfection shape is assumed to be w0 (x) = (L/1000)sin (πx/L). A FE program written in Mathematica language for finding displacement solutions of perfect and imperfect pinned–pinned columns is included in Appendix 2. Numerical integration and equation solving are carried out using Mathematica’s built-in functions NIntegrate and FindRoot, respectively. Because ofthe symmetry about the centre cross-section, only the left half is taken into consideration. The FE solutions for L/h = 20, 30, and 40 are obtained using 20 elements, while for L/h = 100, 40 elements are used. The results are shown in Fig. 12. In this figure, it can be seen that the large deformation beam theory proposed in section 5 predicts relatively more flexible deformation for all the four values of L/h. Also, discrepancies between analytical and FE solutions decrease as L/h increases. This is because at the same load, θof small L/h column is larger than theone of large L/h column. As θincreases, the difference between equations (45), (46), and (48) and equations (1), (2), and (4) becomes more evident. Note that load–deflection curves are traced until the slope is too steep that FindRoot cannot find a converged solution. Next, Table 1 shows convergence of FE solutions as the number of element increases. Itshows the adequacy of 20 and 40 elements used toplot graphs in Fig. 12. Also, it shows the monotonically convergent nature of the proposed FE equations. Fig. 12
Comparison of analytical and FE solutions for various values of slenderness ratio (dotted lines show analytical solutions) Table 1

sec.title: 6.2 Example 2: effect of imperfection magnitude andk
sec.p:
For pinned–pinned columns of L/h20, load–deflection curves are presented in Fig. 13 for various values of imperfection amplitude b1. Also, the curves for various values ofk are shown in Fig. 14. The discrepancies between FE and analytical solutions again depend on the rotation angle of the column. Fig. 13
Comparison of analytical and FE solutions for various values of imperfection amplitude Fig. 14
Comparison of analytical and FE solutions for various values of k

sec.title: 6.3 Example 3: perfect column case
sec.p:
To study the effects of end conditions, the load–deflection curves of a perfect column are plotted inFig. 15 for three types of B.C.: (1) pinned–pinned, (2) clamped–free, and (3) clamped–pinned. For clamped–free and clamped–pinned cases, because the full length of the column should be considered, 40 elements are used. The load–deflection curve of the clamped–free case shows the best agreement between FE and analytical solutions because it shows the deflection of the free tip rather than the centre point. That means that the rotation angle of clamped–free column is the smallest. Fig. 15
Comparison of analytical and FE solutions for various types of B.C. of a perfect column

sec.title: 6.4 Example 4: confirming the value of b1 causing bifurcation
sec.p:
Although the FE equations cannot give a specific value of b1 causing bifurcation, one can still search for the range that must include b1. From Fig. 16, it can be said that such values of b1 for L/h20, 30, 40, and 100 all are close to - (4/π)dz. Fig. 16
Load–deflection curves used to indicate the range that includes b1 causing bifurcation

sec.title: 7 CONCLUSION
sec.p: The displacement functions of the perfect and imperfect FGM columns under a concentric axial point load are derived analytically under the assumptions of a moderately large deflection and von Karman strains. By translating the reference plane to the physical neutral surface position in order to eliminate the coupling between the axial and bending deformations, the displacement functions derived here are in the same form as those of a homogeneous column subjected to an eccentric load. That is, the FGM columns under a concentric load behave like homogeneous columns under an eccentric load. Formulas for finding the position of physical neutral surface as well as effects of material property variation are discussed in section 3. Some issues about geometric imperfection are also studied and it is found that suitable imperfection shapes can theoretically strengthen FGM beams or even cause bifurcation to occur. An example of imperfection shape causing bifurcation is w0 (x) = - (4/π)dzsin(πx/L). Insection 5, FE equations for solving governing equations of a large deformation beam theory are derived. By comparing analytical and FE solutions, it is found that the proposed beam theory predicts relatively larger deflection and discrepancies between the two approaches increase as rotation angle increases.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ref.citation: FeldmanEAboudiJ Buckling analysis of functionally graded plates subjected to uniaxial loading. Compos. Struct, 1997, 38, 29–36.
JavaheriREslamiMR Buckling of functionally graded plates under in-plane compressive loading. ZAMM, 2002, 82(4), 277–283.
